author: Marcus
title: Nextdoor makes it extremely easy to…
text: Nextdoor makes it extremely easy to charge my credit card for their Ads/Pro service, but nearly impossible to cancel the plan, remove my payment information, or speak to a live representative. I attempted multiple times to cancel my subscription and remove my card through their website, but the options are either hidden or unavailable. There is no clear “Cancel Subscription” button, and no reliable customer service phone number. I had to escalate the issue to my bank (Chase), who ultimately removed my card to stop future charges. This practice feels predatory and misleading. Customers should not have to go through their bank just to stop recurring charges. The company should provide: A clear, accessible way to cancel subscriptions online. The ability to remove payment methods without replacing them. A direct way to contact a live customer service representative. Desired Outcome: Immediate cancellation of my account. Written confirmation that no further charges will occur. Assurance that Nextdoor will make subscription cancellation and payment removal more transparent for future customers.

author: Peach Rose
title: Promotes stockers and harassers.
text: I’ve been on Nextdoor for nearly a decade, and it’s disheartening to see how much it’s changed. What once felt like a friendly, casual place for neighbors to share information has turned into a feed filled with ads and sponsored content—sometimes appearing every few posts. The types of posts have also shifted. Lost pets, neighborhood safety concerns, and community disagreements now mix with satire or joke posts that can make the platform feel less constructive. Moderation has also become far stricter. Posts with even a slight political tone seem to disappear immediately, and the current approach feels far more heavy-handed than in the past. Earlier moderators allowed open discussion as long as rules weren’t broken; now, it often feels like decisions are made unilaterally, which has changed the tone of the community. Unfortunately, it’s also become harder to engage without risking harassment. After my first account was compromised, I had to start over, and I’m not willing to go through that a third time. I’ve tried to update my location and maintain my account, but it hasn’t worked smoothly. At this point, it feels like I’m speaking into the void. The sense of community that drew me here has eroded, and the tone of interactions has shifted dramatically. For my own peace of mind, I’m stepping away from Nextdoor and removing it from my routine.

Platforms like Nextdoor claim to build community, but in my experience, they suppress open dialogue, especially when a post doesn’t conform to vague or inconsistently enforced guidelines. There seems to be no accountability, transparency, or real human review. If you're considering joining Nextdoor, know that your account can be restricted without fair notice. Content moderation lacks consistency, and respectful opinions can be taken down arbitrarily. This is especially disappointing for people who genuinely want to engage locally but also care about broader issues that affect us all. I hope Nextdoor re-evaluates how it handles moderation and appeals. Real community isn’t built by silencing voices—it’s built through honest, respectful dialogue.

author: Kevin
title: Avoid Brody HVAC
text: I wanted readers to be aware of the unpleasant experience with Brody HVAC.  I had two vents with no air coming out of them. The Brody tech came and determined I needed to replace a damper.  The price was reasonable although I was surprised that the service charge was not going to the cost of repairs.  So be prepared to pay $85 more than most competing companies.  Brody came to make the repairs and when they finished three vents had no air coming out of them.  I pointed this out to the repair person.  Unfortunately, I had to leave so I told the tech that they would have to return to fix the problem and I’d pay at that time.  The next day I was told someone was on their way to my house. To my surprise it was the owner of the company.  Rather than taking a “how can we make this right” approach to the situation, he had a confrontational demeaner and took the attitude that the damper that was not working was old and probably stopped working while the tech was there.  I said I felt this was too much of a coincidence to be the case.  Rather than arranging for a return trip from one of their repair people, he said I would have to pay the service fee and it would be waived if they were actually at fault.  I encouraged him to at least look at the control panel to see if any wires were dislodged, he showed me that there were two loose wires, but in his opinion, they may have been there from some previous repair and probably did nothing.  Since these wires were the source of the problem, my only assumption is that the owner does not understand how these multi-zoned control boards work, otherwise he would have seen that this was the problem and corrected it.  I went ahead and set up an appointment for a tech to come to the house and while on the way over the owner called me to tell me that the tech would not come unless I immediately paid the invoice.  I told him I planned to pay while he was at my house.  He obviously didn’t trust me and demanded payment.  I felt over a barrel and paid as demanded.  Unsurprisingly the tech came and quickly realized that the first tech that came to the house had disconnected the damper (hence the two unattached wires at the control panel that the owner noticed) and all that needed to be done was reconnect them.  Guess what?  All three vents now worked fine.  My point is that if you believe you should pay for a service whether it is done correctly or not, then Brody is your kind of company.  However, if you think the service should be paid for only if you are satisfied with the results then I would recommend you look elsewhere.  If you withhold payment due to poor service, be warned that you will receive a visit from the owner of the company who will demand payment before doing anything to address your complaints.  His tech people are fantastic, The owner, not so much.  He needs to concentrate on customer satisfaction rather than play the part of a collection agency.  He also needs to get some basic training from his techs on how to make repairs to a multi-zoned control panel!!

author: Todd Riches
title: Does not foster community engagement and information sharing
text: Nextdoor was originally intended to be a social media platform that fosters community engagement and facilitates easy information sharing among neighbors. Unfortunately, it has strayed significantly from that mission. In my experience, it has become: A platform where users are often criticized or berated for commenting on posts outside of their immediate neighborhood. A space where individuals frequently request handouts rather than seeking solutions or offering mutual support. A service that compromises user privacy — despite using a fictitious name, I began receiving unsolicited emails addressed to that name from companies I had no prior interactions with. An environment with ineffective moderation — during my time as a moderator, I observed widespread bias and a lack of accountability, with many moderators failing to act on clear violations of community guidelines. After deleting my account for a second time, I have decided not to return. In its current state, Nextdoor no longer offers the positive, community-driven experience it originally promised.
